> But what if you're not allowed to see the code?  That is, what if 
> you're testing the implementation of a vendor's code who's source you 
> can neither see nor modify?


Normally you should only write tests for a vendor's code if :
- you want to learn how the method works
- you want to reproduce a bug
- you're paid to do it

In any of these cases, you're doing black box testing, and you must only 
use the public interface for testing.  Because that's how a client 
application will use the vendor's code.

Calling a method of the public interface must have some kind of result 
that is accessible through another method of this interface (or event, 
or exception).  In case of event dispatching, simply use mock-objects to 
implement a listener (as described by Mike in a previous mail).

-Vladimir
